item.title: Logitech CEO Hanneke Faber wants your next mouse to last forever
item.content:encoded:
https://www.theverge.com/24206847/logitech-ceo-hanneke-faber-mouse-keyboard-gaming-decoder-podcast-interview

Today, I‚Äôm talking with Hanneke Faber, the CEO of Logitech. Hanneke‚Äôs still pretty new to the role: she joined the company last October, after the former CEO, Bracken Darrell, left.

You might remember Bracken ‚Äî he was on Decoder back in 2021, basically at the height of the covid-19 pandemic-era boom in home office sales, when Logitech was selling mice, keyboards, and webcams as fast as it could make them. 

Obviously, things have changed since then. Logitech, like so many companies that saw huge pandemic booms, very abruptly saw that growth slow down when the world began to normalize. Bracken left Logitech last June to go to the company that owns Vans and Supreme, and Logitech brought on Hanneke, a longtime executive with an extensive background in consumer goods at conglomerates like Unilever and Procter & Gamble.

Listen to Decoder, a show hosted by The Verge‚Äôs Nilay Patel about big ideas ‚Äî and other problems. Subscribe here!

Hanneke and I talked about the structural changes she‚Äôs already making at Logitech and the changes she intends to make in the future. It sounds like some Logitech products, like its smart home doorbells and cameras, are not long for this world.

Hanneke says that people often say ‚Äúthe mouse built this house‚Äù inside Logitech, which is a delightful catchphrase I‚Äôd never heard before. From there, we talked about how new interface paradigms like voice and AI might upend mice and keyboards and how she‚Äôs thinking about the company‚Äôs long-term future in a world where traditional PC sales might go down.

Of course, we talked about whether anyone wants their mouse to be anything more than a mouse ‚Äî Logitech is adding AI features and even AI buttons to some of its products, and I wanted to know if that‚Äôs working. 

You‚Äôll hear Hanneke talk about a concept called the ‚Äúforever mouse,‚Äù or a mouse you buy once and upgrade over time with new software features ‚Äî features that, of course, might carry a subscription fee. Subscription mice! It‚Äôs a lot.

You‚Äôll also hear Hanneke talk about how she plans to grow the business and hit an ambitious carbon footprint reduction milestone by the end of the decade as well as where she thinks the company needs to go next. There‚Äôs a lot in this one.

Okay, Logitech CEO Hanneke Faber. Here we go.

This transcript has been lightly edited for length and clarity. 

Hanneke Faber, you are the new-ish CEO of Logitech. Welcome to Decoder.

Thank you so much.

I am really excited to talk to you. You have been on the job as CEO for seven months now?

Seven months. I started on December 1st.

So you‚Äôre in. You‚Äôre settled. You know where the bathrooms are, which is step one.

Yeah, for sure. Although today‚Äôs my first day actually in the office in California. I‚Äôve been in Switzerland so far, so you catch me on day one.

Well, I‚Äôm just going to ask you where different things are in that office for the rest of the hour. 

[Laughs] 

Logitech is a fascinating company. It‚Äôs one of those companies that I think is undercover. When we started Decoder, one of our first ideas was that we should talk to more than five CEOs, and Logitech is one of those companies that is just ever-present in the world of technology. It is a partner to the big companies. It‚Äôs in everyone‚Äôs office. It‚Äôs in lots of people‚Äôs homes. It‚Äôs basically a core fixture of gaming. You play in a lot of spaces.

I talked to your predecessor, Bracken Darrell, in the middle of the covid-19 pandemic in 2021, when everything was a lot different. Sales were skyrocketing, and he changed his strategy a little bit. Bracken recently left. He now runs Supreme and Vans, which was a shift. We‚Äôll talk to him about that. You have a background in consumer goods at Procter & Gamble and Unilever. Why jump to Logitech when the job opened up?

Actually, Bracken came from P&G as well, so that‚Äôs not so different. But I‚Äôve been really fortunate throughout my career of working in different industries. I worked mostly in beauty at P&G. I actually worked in tech for four years at Ahold Delhaize. I ran their e-commerce business when it was almost nonexistent. We built a really cool online grocery business. And then, for the last six years, I ran Unilever‚Äôs global food business.

So [despite being] different businesses, I think there are some themes that apply to Logitech: a focus on the user and the consumer first; a focus on innovation and product. And then, finally, really global footprints in every job I‚Äôve worked in and a mix of B2B and B2C. All of those things do translate. Of course, this is a new industry and a new company for me, but it‚Äôs great to bring a whole bunch of things that I have experience with and learn a few new things as well.

One of the things that‚Äôs really interesting to me about Logitech is that people tend to think of its core products ‚Äî mice, keyboards, headsets, webcams ‚Äî as commodities, but they‚Äôre still technology products. There‚Äôs a lot of innovation left in those spaces. Logitech has driven some of that innovation, but then you see other weird things blossom into cultures unto themselves ‚Äî mechanical keyboards, for example. There are webcam startups again, which is really interesting. That was not a thing that was happening pre-covid. 

Do you view the opportunity here as an operational opportunity, as an innovation opportunity, as a ‚Äúfind new categories and make them grow‚Äù opportunity? What is your macro view of the situation?

There are three main tailwinds on our core business. The first one is new ways of working, hybrid working. That‚Äôs good for our personal workspace business, the traditional mice and keyboards, because everyone needs multiple setups. And obviously it‚Äôs good for our video conferencing business. So the new ways of working post-covid are a real tailwind for us. 

Second is gaming. Gaming, just as a space, continues to grow, and especially with new demographics. Almost half of gamers are now women, which is amazing. And older people game. It‚Äôs no longer just teenage boys. We see the market continue to grow.

Wait, can I ask you one question about older people in that context? 

Yeah. Sorry, older than teenage boys?

Sure. Is it that a set of teenage boys who were gamers 15 years ago got older, or is it older people are becoming new gamers?

I think we‚Äôre seeing a little bit of both, although it‚Äôs probably the first trend that is the biggest one. The teenage boys of 15 years ago are now in their 30s and 40s, so that just extends the demographic. New teenage boys are still coming in, and girls, so that‚Äôs good. But we‚Äôre also seeing older cohorts coming in mostly through mobile, through Candy Crush but also Wordle and Connections. Those are entry points into gaming that make them more comfortable with gaming and may take them to PC and console gaming as well.

You said there was a third thing. What was the third thing?

The third thing‚Ä¶ of course you can‚Äôt do an interview for three minutes and not say AI, but AI is a real tailwind for us as well.

How do you think AI is a tailwind for Logitech in particular?

In three ways. First, like for any other company, is internal productivity. We‚Äôre seeing it on the software engineering side, where coding and testing have clearly become more efficient, but we‚Äôre also seeing it on the creative and brand-building side, again, where things are getting more efficient but also sometimes more creative. 

More importantly, on the product side, there are two ways in which AI will be a tailwind. First of all, we‚Äôve always been a human-to-technology interface company, and we‚Äôre starting to be an interface to the large language models. A couple of months ago, we launched the Logi AI Prompt Builder, which is basically a shortcut in our software to ChatGPT. It has millions of unique users already, and it‚Äôs just a simpler way for people to use ChatGPT and not get out of their flow when they use all of our mice and keyboards in English-speaking countries. There will be much more to follow in terms of being that human-technology interface.

There‚Äôs a third area that is big on AI, which is in audio and video. We have a big video conferencing business, a headphones business. That‚Äôs really machine learning and large data models, and the company‚Äôs been at those for a number of years, but we‚Äôre seeing the quality of things like two-way noise cancellation or video conferencing equipment that actually knows when to zoom in on you when you‚Äôre speaking and not when you‚Äôre opening a packet of crisps. Those kinds of things are really important, and I foresee massive quality improvements thanks to machine learning in the years ahead.

I want to come back to the AI question because I think there‚Äôs a lot to unpack there, and there are a lot of obvious opportunities, like you said, in audio and video. And then there are some opportunities that, I think, deserve a little more time around AI prompt building and that sort of thing. 

But I want to stay focused for a second on you. You‚Äôre the new CEO. So covid, work from home, created a massive opportunity for Logitech. I bought a black market webcam at the end of 2020. It was Chinese. It wasn‚Äôt even meant for this market.

I love it.

The previous administration really ramped production. They saw huge growth. Then there was an enterprise push as more and more companies embraced hybrid and remote and refitted all their conference rooms. That all crashed back to earth, and there were a couple of years when the growth was falling. Logitech‚Äôs fourth quarter earnings released back in April marked your first quarter of sales growth in over two years. You also reported growth in your most recent quarter. What is bringing that growth back?

Product innovation and markets that are stabilizing a little bit post-covid [are contributing to that growth]. I have to say, this company should be very proud of what it did during covid under Bracken. It did a really great job, but obviously it was a bit of a sugar high. That said, the company is 50 percent bigger today than it was pre-covid, so it hasn‚Äôt all come crashing down to earth. 

I think what we‚Äôve done is we‚Äôve really been focusing on great execution and on things that we can control. There are some things that we can‚Äôt control: inflation, consumer confidence, corporate IT budgets for our video conferencing business. But within those constraints, we‚Äôve been growing our share. That was one of the drivers of us getting back to growth in Q4. We‚Äôve been delivering really exciting innovation, and we‚Äôll continue to do those things.

You called it a sugar high. I feel like the broad story of tech in particular is the sugar high of overinvestment during covid, of competing to hire every single person that existed in the world who could write code and then assuming that those trends would be permanent and we would all stay inside and live our lives mediated through screens on the internet forever. Many companies did not survive that sugar high. Is it that simple, that Logitech just weathered the covid highs and the trends and is back to a stable place now?

We‚Äôre not back to where we were in 2019. Again, we‚Äôre 50 percent bigger as a company, and the way people work is so different today versus 2019. Virtually every company that I speak to, and I speak to many of them because they‚Äôre all our customers, wants to be hybrid. They want their people to come into the office two or three days a week, but they also want to offer the flexibility of working from home or working from anywhere. That is obviously very different from in 2019. We pride ourselves on being a model for ways of working because we sell this stuff, so I think we‚Äôre very well positioned to help our corporate customers give people a great experience both in the office and at home.

You mentioned that you are in the California office today, and it‚Äôs your first day there. You moved to Switzerland when you got this job. How are you structuring your time between remote, hybrid, and in person? How‚Äôs that working for you?

Sadly, I live on an airplane, it feels like. Logitech is very special in that it is a super global company. We‚Äôre on the ground in more than 100 countries, and we have great capabilities around the world. I spend probably 60 percent of my time in offices that are not my own. When I‚Äôm in California, or I spent these first seven months [on the job] in our Swiss office, I try to be in the office. But I might also, if I start early ‚Äî like today, I started at 6AM ‚Äî go back home at 1PM and get some exercise and then work more later on. That‚Äôs a level of flexibility that I don‚Äôt think we necessarily had pre-covid, which is great.

Do you ever find yourself in that horrible situation of being alone in a conference room on a video call?

That‚Äôs just ridiculous, right?

That‚Äôs my nightmare. If I go to the office and I‚Äôm the only one there and everyone else is on a video call, I wonder why we even have an office.

[Laughs] Yeah, absolutely. Well, we have this concept of gravity days at Logitech. On the gravity days, everyone‚Äôs there so you‚Äôre not by yourself.

What are the gravity days?

It depends on the teams. My gravity days here are Tuesdays and Wednesdays, so I‚Äôll see most of the leadership team. But different teams have different gravity days that they pick themselves.

And then are you living on a plane just to be in person wherever you need to be?

Yes, and part of that is because I‚Äôm new ‚Äî and I‚Äôm not just new to the company; I‚Äôm also new to the industry. I need to meet people, our own people, but very much also suppliers, customers, consumers, investors. There are just a lot of people to meet, and certainly a first meeting, I think, is still best done in person.

This brings us very neatly to what I think of as the Decoder questions. I was listening to the first fireside chat you had for your investors five days into the job, and I heard you say that your style is to be as close to the customer and as close to the people doing the work as possible because they know best. That‚Äôs you on planes. But ultimately, you have to make a lot of decisions. What kind of decisions do you want to be making? What‚Äôs your framework for making them?

I think company strategy is a great way to set that decision framework. I‚Äôve spent a lot of time in the last six months, first listening, then co-creating that strategy, and then setting the strategy and setting the bar high. If I unpack that a little bit, there‚Äôs lots of stuff I don‚Äôt know and that we all don‚Äôt know, so listening was first. Then we sat down with the leadership team first to really make choices. What‚Äôs our goal? For 2031, because that‚Äôs when Logitech will be 50 years old, we set a goal of doubling the business and reducing our carbon footprint by 50 percent while retaining really attractive margins. 

We set a mission, which we‚Äôve said is extending human potential in work and in play. We had a good mission, but it was three pages long, so I really wanted to simplify that. And ‚Äúextending human potential,‚Äù those words are carefully chosen. So ‚Äúextending‚Äù is obviously a riff on the mouse. The mouse built this house. It extends your arm, so we want to extend‚Äî

You say, ‚ÄúThe mouse built this house‚Äù?

Yeah, that‚Äôs what they say here ‚Äî and I say it. I like it.

That should be the whole mission, I got to be honest with you. I think it‚Äôs a strong contender. 

That‚Äôs right. But we extend human potential in this age of AI, this age of [Zoom CEO] Eric Yuan saying there are digital twins of all of us coming to meetings. It‚Äôs really important that we extend human potential because we can make humans better. We can help you win that game. We can help you be more productive. We can help you connect better when you‚Äôre in that conference room by yourself. If we can do that in ways that are also healthier for people on the planet, then extending human potential is really worth waking up for every morning.

And what else is there in life but work and play? We do that in work and play today, but I believe, with my leadership team, that those areas are actually much bigger than where Logitech plays today. Today, we‚Äôre mostly focused on work. We focus on office workers. Most people in the world don‚Äôt work in an office. They work in retail, healthcare, education, construction, you name it. And we can play there, too. And in gaming, we‚Äôre mostly focused on PC gaming. Today, there‚Äôs a lot more play out there than just PC gaming. That broadens our TAM, our total addressable market, for the future, which is an opportunity to deliver that growth.

That‚Äôs a long-winded way of saying what we‚Äôre doing. That is our framework for decision-making. We‚Äôve then made some pretty clear choices where to play and how to win below that, and now that that is in place, as a leader, I can circle back and say, ‚ÄúOkay, I listened. We co-create it and we set the bar high.‚Äù Now, I circle back and I listen again. I go back and I listen to people and say, ‚ÄúWhat do they need? What obstacles do I need to take away so that they can deliver on doubling the business and reducing the carbon footprint by half?‚Äù

What kind of obstacles have you removed so far?

Well, we‚Äôre in the process [of doing this]. I think some of those obstacles might be the result of that sugar high. We got a little complicated in our organization because we had a lot of people, and that usually makes things a little more complicated. So we‚Äôre about to do some simplifications and also invest some more money in areas where we‚Äôre maybe not quite as good as we need to be. 

Historically, we‚Äôre a fantastic B2C company. We sell our stuff to Amazon, to Best Buy, to MediaMarkt. That‚Äôs who we are. B2B is much newer. And again, Bracken and the team did a great job of building a B2B business from scratch with a really disruptive video conferencing product. But we‚Äôre like teenagers in that space. I wouldn‚Äôt call us babies, but we‚Äôre like teenagers. If you compare our capabilities, especially on the go-to-market side, to some of the more legacy players in B2B, we‚Äôre just newer. That‚Äôs a place where we will be investing, and that‚Äôs been an obstacle.

You have brought up changing the org chart, which is bait for the show. That‚Äôs what Decoder is all about. When I talked to Bracken last, I will never forget it, he described one of the most complicated org charts I‚Äôve ever heard. It seemed to be working. He seemed to be happy with it. He told me, and I went and looked it up, he had 23 direct reports. Most of the teams across the company were set up to be almost completely independent, and he was totally fine with duplicated efforts and resources. 

So if two teams were both going to do microphones, that was fine as long as they were both going to market and the teams independently were profitable or successful in their own way. I think he told me there were something like 20 or 30 product teams just running under the various brands. That feels like the thing you‚Äôre about to change. Is that what you‚Äôre changing?

Yeah, and again, I don‚Äôt want to blame previous setups because they were working for their time. The track record of value creation here at Logitech is fantastic. But I think now what I‚Äôm hearing from our people and what we‚Äôre seeing in some of the results over the past few years is that we do need to simplify because things have gotten a little bit too complicated. 

Part of that, by the way, is the brand story. Logitech tried to become a multi-brand company, but today, 97 percent of our sales are in the Logitech brand, Logitech and Logitech G, and I consider those one brand, really. So it‚Äôs important that we make sure that 97 percent of our resources are focused on that brand and that we don‚Äôt get too scattered around the company. That‚Äôs one of the other strategic choices that we‚Äôve made: we will build one fantastic iconic Logitech brand, and that‚Äôs our focus.

A lot of the other brands you‚Äôre describing are the result of acquisitions. There‚Äôs Ultimate Ears, Jaybird, Blue Microphones, Streamlabs ‚Äî and the list goes on. There have been a lot of acquisitions and there are a lot of new products. Then there are attempts to be more consumer with the Logi brand. Is all of that stuff going to come in under Logitech, or are you going to leave those alone?

Well, again, it‚Äôs the tail wagging the dog, right? It‚Äôs very, very small. And some of it has already been folded in successfully under the Logitech brand. If you look at Astro, which was a really good acquisition, it‚Äôs now part of Logitech. That makes a lot of sense. And it absolutely doesn‚Äôt mean we won‚Äôt do acquisitions in the future, but again, when they can be folded in, they probably should. 

There are much, much bigger companies with much bigger brands that don‚Äôt rely on a whole stable of brands. So I‚Äôm excited about that. And then you also mentioned product development and engineering, which, of course, is the heart of this company. Again, there‚Äôs probably room for a little bit more synergy, and this is, by the way, not about cost-cutting. It‚Äôs just about getting more out of the resources that we have if we talk to each other a little bit more.

I‚Äôm assuming you‚Äôre not going to stick with 23 direct reports and a bunch of basically startup founders everywhere. 

I already haven‚Äôt, that I know.

To your point, it worked.

Absolutely.

I remember talking to Bracken. I was like, ‚ÄúThat sounds pretty fun,‚Äù and he seemed like he was having a good time. But you need to change it now. How are you doing that? What‚Äôs the structure now?

I‚Äôm already down to 12 or 13 direct reports, so it‚Äôs already streamlined in that way. I think running the company along the lines of three big businesses ‚Äî personal workspace, gaming, and Logitech for enterprise ‚Äî is a really important way of going forward, and that‚Äôs what we‚Äôll be doing. 

Again, historically, we‚Äôre very much a consumer company, so across [personal workspace solutions] and gaming, we‚Äôll be focused on the end user to consumer, the customer, Amazon, Walmart, Gigabyte, MediaMarkt, etc. And B2B is a different kettle of fish where we still have to build significant capability, which is a huge opportunity because, again, we‚Äôve got fabulous products for corporate customers, and our penetration is still very low. So I‚Äôm really excited about the growth potential of our B2B business.

Inside of that structure, which feels like a go-to-market structure, you‚Äôve got the three big consumer segments, and you‚Äôve got products that might move between them. You do still have some brands that people love. Ultimate Ears is a brand that I love. That was my first fancy pair of headphones. You have Blue Microphones, where half or a quarter of the podcasts in the world are on fancy Blue Microphones, and they‚Äôre a fixture of all the studios. Are you going to leave some of those to their high-end customers?

Yeah, absolutely, and we retain a small Ultimate Ears team who are doing great stuff. They just launched the new Wonderboom, which is a super cool product. The same is true for Blue. Absolutely, those little teams, again, we‚Äôre super sufficient and scrappy on those, but they‚Äôre great products and they‚Äôll stay in place and they‚Äôre as loved as the big dogs.

When you were going through and saying, ‚ÄúOkay, I have to fold some into the three big buckets and I‚Äôm going to leave some of these alone,‚Äù what was the framework you used? What was the marker for you to say, ‚ÄúOkay, we‚Äôre going to set Blue aside, but this one we have to fold into the main consumer Logitech brand‚Äù?

I think the framework is a framework of growth. So if we want to double the business by 2031, then you work back and you say, ‚ÄúOkay, what do we need to do?‚Äù Well, we need to grow organically, mid-single digits, and we want to do some M&A. What are the spaces that we‚Äôll play in? It will be work and play and it will be B2B and B2C. Then, when you look at the building blocks, the big chunks will be in B2B video conferencing and personal workspace products, in gaming and in PWS products. 

So then, underneath that, yes, you have to fit in some of these smaller pieces, and that‚Äôs totally fine. I‚Äôve always found throughout my career that it‚Äôs actually fun to work on some of these smaller pieces because you have a little more freedom. If you do well, people think you‚Äôre fantastic. If you don‚Äôt do well, it doesn‚Äôt really matter. So that‚Äôs a nice place to be in.

One of the other things you said in that investor call, which is also just pure Decoder bait and I thank you for it, is that one of your core beliefs is that companies are perfectly designed to get the results that they are getting. Whatever result you get you can just run right back to the structure of the company. Explain that in more depth.

The results that we got last quarter, which we‚Äôre actually pleased with because we were back to growth and we had really good margins, are the result of the structure that we had then. Now, I‚Äôm a big believer that you have to make a few changes if you want to get, in our case, even better results, a little faster growth with the same margins, and not unimportantly, reduce that carbon footprint by 50 percent. If you expect the same results, then it‚Äôs fine to stay with that same organization. If you expect results that are a little different, you need to make some tweaks. Again, I don‚Äôt think Logitech is a disaster turnaround story at all. This is a good-to-great story. But if we want to be great, then we have to make some tweaks.

As you think about changing the structure, you talked about your process here tonight. You talked to everybody. You listened. You co-created some ideas. There are some goals here. You‚Äôre saying, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm designing a structure to get to some very explicit, probably measurable goals.‚Äù Do those look mostly like growth? Does it look like product innovation? Does it look like flipping the apple cart over and inventing the next iPhone?

This is a product and innovation company at its heart. So that‚Äôs the way we grow, with great, fantastic products that our users love. But that‚Äôs the what and the how. In terms of the outcome, yes, it‚Äôs about growth. So we‚Äôve said we want to double the business by 2031 and reduce our carbon footprint because that‚Äôs something the company committed to well before I got here, which is not so easy to do when you double your business because each one of those mice and keyboards emits more carbon. Then, of course, we want to create great value for investors. So gross margins and operating income margins are important, and we‚Äôve guided for some really attractive levels.

You‚Äôre the new CEO. You got hired by a board of directors. Some of that board of directors is leaving. You‚Äôre going to have some new members that the shareholders can vote for. You‚Äôd like them to vote for you to be added to the board of directors. 

When you set that goal and you say, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm changing the structure of the company,‚Äù or even when you‚Äôre interviewing for the job, did you come in and say, ‚ÄúLook, I think we should double the size of the company by 2031‚Äù? Was that the pitch? Was it, ‚ÄúI think there‚Äôs a new vision‚Äù? Now, when you‚Äôre actually executing and saying these things out loud, do you feel the pressure to grow from your investors or your board members? Where does that come from?

I would say, first of all, on the process to get this role, kudos to the board of Logitech. I thought they did a really great job in the interviewing process, where, I‚Äôll spill the beans, but they asked each of the candidates to do a 15- to 20-minute presentation on what they thought the company should be. Now, of course, as an external candidate, you do that not knowing a whole lot. 

So, while some of the themes I talked about have come back in my actual strategy, some of the things have changed because obviously I know a lot more now than I did before I joined. But that was helpful because it allows the board to see where the candidate wants to take the company. But you‚Äôd be surprised that not all boards do that. 

So that was the hiring process. You didn‚Äôt walk in saying, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to double the size of the company.‚Äù But now is when you‚Äôre saying that? 

Yes.

And is that a decision that is coming from the board in service to its investors?

No. Again, this is listening, co-creating, and then engaging with the board deeply on ‚Äúdoes this make sense ‚Äî these goals, this vision?‚Äù And then these ‚Äúwhere to play‚Äù and ‚Äúhow to win‚Äù choices, do those make sense? The board was a really important stakeholder, obviously, in finalizing that. But so were the people of Logitech. I‚Äôm a big believer in co-creation, and that‚Äôs not just co-creation with the leadership team. 

We actually invited all 7,000 employees to come to co-creation sessions around the world where we shared with them an MVP of our strategy. But then we said, ‚ÄúTell us three things you‚Äôd like and three things you want to add or change.‚Äù We had great feedback on that, and that really shaped the final strategy.

What was the biggest thing that you added or changed or the biggest thing that people really liked?

What they really liked is the continued focus on products and innovation. Again, that is our lifeblood, and we have so many fantastic engineers and designers, so that came out very, very clearly. I think what surprised me was actually the passion for sustainability. There‚Äôs a huge passion around the world for what we can do to lead in tech on reducing the carbon footprint where there‚Äôs a lot of greenwashing and a lot of increasing carbon footprints, unfortunately, in the age of AI. There was more passion for that topic than I had expected. So again, it‚Äôs important in our strategy going forward.

Let‚Äôs talk about the products. They are the lifeblood of the company. I‚Äôm going to say ‚Äúthe mouse built this house‚Äù all the time. It‚Äôs very good. I can‚Äôt believe I never knew that before. It‚Äôs a pretty sprawling product lineup. You‚Äôre in a million categories. How did you acquaint yourself with all of it?

There are three big ones. 

Well, sure, but everything from smart home doorbells to mice to headphones, it‚Äôs a lot of things.

I think those are pretty much gone.

So wait, you‚Äôre going to leave the smart home?

No, there‚Äôs our timing. I need to double-check, but I‚Äôm not even sure those are still being sold. It‚Äôs really personal workspace, video conferencing, and gaming.

What about all the customers you sold smart home cameras to who have cloud service dependencies?

We‚Äôll continue to support, of course, what we‚Äôve sold for some time.

I‚Äôm always curious because every new category now has some sort of ongoing service dependency, which feels very risky. Our audience is constantly telling us that one reason they go back to big companies over and over again and won‚Äôt buy products from challengers or startups is that they don‚Äôt want their products to disappear. And then big companies like Google have broken that trust anyway. This is a really ongoing conversation with The Verge audience. It must be new for you. When you were at Procter & Gamble, I‚Äôm assuming people didn‚Äôt buy shampoo and then worry you were going to stop selling shampoo.

That‚Äôs so true, and it‚Äôs such an interesting topic. Actually, at Procter & Gamble, we did get lots of people calling when you took their lipstick shade out, but that‚Äôs a little different. There‚Äôs no software inside.

Yeah, you weren‚Äôt breaking all the existing lipsticks that had been sold.

Exactly. Again, this is a space that‚Äôs somewhat newer for Logitech, but it‚Äôs incredibly strategic. We don‚Äôt do just pure hardware. We do design-led, software-enabled hardware, and that software component in the age of AI is more important every day. The services that we provide to our corporate customers are actually a nicely growing part of the business that didn‚Äôt exist a few years ago because Logitech was new to B2B and wasn‚Äôt charging for its services. Now we are. 

I think we deliver great software services to our B2B customers, but we are learning. On the consumer side as well, through Logitech Options Plus, the software, it‚Äôs very important to deliver superior products for our users. We now have more software engineers than hardware engineers, which is a big milestone.

This comes up in surprising ways on Decoder. The CTO of John Deere once told me that John Deere has more software engineers than hardware engineers because it has to support the ongoing service and cloud capabilities of the tractor. This makes a little more sense for Logitech, but really what we‚Äôre talking about is an ongoing cost. You sell me the keyboard once. It‚Äôs got Options Plus. It has an AI button. I push the button, and someone has to make sure the software still works. Someone probably has to pay ChatGPT for access to the service. Where is that going to come from? Are you baking that into the margin of the keyboard or the mouse?

Absolutely. We‚Äôre baking that in, and I‚Äôm not particularly worried about that. What I‚Äôm actually hoping is that this will contribute to the longevity of our products, that we‚Äôll have more premium products but products that last longer because they‚Äôre superior and because we can continue to update them over time. And again, I talked about doubling the business and reducing the carbon footprint by half. The longevity piece is really important.

I‚Äôm very intrigued. The other day, in Ireland, in our innovation center there, one of our team members showed me a forever mouse with the comparison to a watch. This is a nice watch, not a super expensive watch, but I‚Äôm not planning to throw that watch away ever. So why would I be throwing my mouse or my keyboard away if it‚Äôs a fantastic-quality, well-designed, software-enabled mouse. The forever mouse is one of the things that we‚Äôd like to get to.

What made the mouse a forever mouse?

It was a little heavier, it had great software and services that you‚Äôd constantly update, and it was beautiful. So I don‚Äôt think we‚Äôre necessarily super far away from that.

But, again, I just come back to the cost. You sell me the mouse once. Maybe I‚Äôll pay 200 bucks for it.

The business model obviously is the challenge there. So then software is even more important when you think about it. Can you come up with a service model? In our video conferencing business, that is now a very important part of the model, the services, and it‚Äôs critical for corporate customers.

Let‚Äôs come to that in a second because that makes sense to me. You sell managed services to enterprises. You price support contracts for cameras and whatever. That‚Äôs an ongoing need businesses have. I‚Äôm still stuck on, ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre going to sell me a mouse once and it‚Äôs going to have ongoing software updates forever.‚Äù

Imagine it‚Äôs like your Rolex. You‚Äôre going to really love that.

But Rolex has to employ software engineers to ship me over-the-air updates forever.

But the artifact is like your Rolex, and then given that we know the technology that we attach to changes, it‚Äôs not going to be like your Rolex in that it doesn‚Äôt have to ever change. Our stuff will have to change, but does the hardware have to change? I‚Äôm not so sure. We‚Äôll have to obviously fix it and figure out what that business model is. We‚Äôre not at the forever mouse today, but I‚Äôm intrigued by the thought.

It certainly will help with sustainability. There are two ways people have traditionally proposed monetizing hardware over time. It‚Äôs subscription fees and it‚Äôs advertising. Is there a third way that I don‚Äôt know about that you‚Äôre thinking of?

No. The third way is the traditional model of ‚Äúwe innovate and we have you upgrade.‚Äù That‚Äôs the current model. And we‚Äôre pretty damn good at that model because we have pretty damn good innovators around the company who do come up with fabulous products. 

That is definitely the model today. It‚Äôs not a bad model at all, especially since we‚Äôre continuing to design for more sustainable products. We‚Äôre continuing to recycle and refurbish products. All of that is good. But that said, I am intrigued by a forever mouse or forever video conferencing solution that you just update with software and create a business model around that.

I‚Äôm going to ask this very directly. Can you envision a subscription mouse?

Possibly.

And that would be the forever mouse?

Yeah.

So you pay a subscription for software updates to your mouse.

Yeah, and you never have to worry about it again, which is not unlike our video conferencing services today.

But it‚Äôs a mouse.

But it‚Äôs a mouse, yeah.

I think consumers might perceive those to be very different. 

[Laughs] Yes, but it‚Äôs gorgeous. Think about it like a diamond-encrusted mouse.

You mentioned AI earlier. You have rolled out some of the AI features in the new versions of Options Plus. There is a mouse with an AI button.

Actually, sorry, Nilay. I am going to give you just a little piece of information. So the mouse built this house. Is that a traditional category? Will it go away? Is it old and tired? We don‚Äôt believe so because only about 50 percent of people use a mouse and a keyboard today, a separate keyboard.

Some only have a mouse or only a keyboard, but many of them have both. But the thing that shocked me was that the average spend on that globally is $26, which is really so low. This is stuff you use every day, that sits on your desk every day, that you look at every day. That‚Äôs like the price of four coffees at Starbucks or less than a Nike running shirt. There is so much room to create more value in that space as we make people more productive ‚Äî to extend human potential.

Do you think the growth comes from going from 50 to 55 percent, or does it come from selling the 50 percent more expensive products? 

Both. Absolutely both. That‚Äôs why this is still an exciting category.

One of the things about keyboards in particular is that they have become lifestyle items. You see influencers on TikTok talk about their setups. We run photos of people‚Äôs setups. People have deep abiding attachments to their key switches in their keyboards. I‚Äôm assuming this is new to you, unless you were a diehard mechanical keyboard fan before, which would be amazing. You‚Äôre looking at it from a background in consumer products. What‚Äôs your view of that, of the keyboard as a lifestyle product?

I definitely think it‚Äôs an important lifestyle product. Obviously, on the gaming side, it‚Äôs a really important lifestyle product, and again, it‚Äôs a real growth opportunity for us for many years to come. On the work side, what I‚Äôm intrigued by is that the needs of different people are very different when it comes to keyboards and mice. So we have done a nice job of growing this business by targeting different groups. 

You have advanced users: a software engineer; a financial analyst who is in Excel all day. They need our MX line where you can do tons of shortcuts. I met someone over the weekend who ‚Äî I didn‚Äôt even know this was possible ‚Äî had done 120 shortcuts on one of our mice. I‚Äôm like, ‚ÄúWhat? I‚Äôm proud I have four.‚Äù But anyway, these are super advanced users, and we make MX products for them.

Then you have people who have some wellness issues because they‚Äôre also typing all day, but they‚Äôre sitting at the kitchen table or on an airplane like me, and they‚Äôre screwing up their arms. So the Ergo line ‚Äî also very premium, very beautiful ‚Äî is really made for them. I use an Ergo keyboard. It‚Äôs fantastic. It really helps on the shoulder and the arm. Then you have more lifestyle, younger people, especially in China, who want the pink mouse or who want the mouse that goes with the latest game. So these are really different groups, and I think we have opportunities to go even deeper on those consumer needs to build exactly the right products for them.

That differentiation between gaming and professional and lifestyle, you can pull them apart. I think a lot of companies try to pull them apart. But I think, from my view, they‚Äôre getting mashed together. The needs of a gamer and the needs of the Excel macro fanatic, they‚Äôre more the same than different in some cases. And then the high-design lifestyle category and gaming as a lifestyle are also the same in very important ways. How do you pull those apart? What‚Äôs your approach to that, especially because you have a view from the outside?

Absolutely. It‚Äôs funny. It‚Äôs an ‚Äúand, and.‚Äù In some cases, you‚Äôre absolutely right, things are blurring. In China, we‚Äôre seeing a lot of people working with our gaming stuff, but then there‚Äôs also complete bifurcation. Our top-of-the-line gaming mouse is the Pro Light, which is the most simplistic-looking from the outside: a super light, thin thing with a lot of exciting software inside. Whereas our top-of-the-line MX mouse for advanced users is not at all minimalistic because it has 18 buttons and scrollers and whatever. You‚Äôll see the same guy who‚Äôs a software engineer by day and a gamer by night use both. So it‚Äôs a ‚Äúyes, and.‚Äù And again, it‚Äôs really important we understand all of those users and that we build fabulous products for them.

The really interesting thing about keyboards and mice is that they‚Äôre tied to desktop computing as a paradigm, particularly mice. You can plug a mouse into an iPad, but why? You can buy the case, and Apple has a lot of decisions to make about the future of the iPad, but really what we‚Äôre talking about is desktop computers: macOS, Windows, Linux, big monitors maybe.

There‚Äôs an endless prediction that this will go away, that mobile will take over everything. That prediction does not appear to have borne out. When you‚Äôre thinking about Logitech‚Äôs markets, how do you evaluate that? Is it that eventually everyone will just have a phone and the laptop will go away? Even if the evidence doesn‚Äôt seem to bear it out, it is a permanent prediction in the tech industry.

It‚Äôs definitely a permanent prediction. As I onboarded at the company, I had a few history lessons. I went through historical documents, and this same thing came up 20‚Äì25 years ago: the PC is imminently disappearing. That has not happened, but that doesn‚Äôt mean we shouldn‚Äôt absolutely be paranoid. One of our innovation streams is called ‚ÄúBeyond the PC,‚Äù and we‚Äôre dedicating significant resources to innovating beyond the PC.

Of course, some of what we sell today, quite a good amount of what we sell today, video conferencing, is already beyond the PC. That‚Äôs important. If you look at one of our recent innovations, we announced two weeks ago the MX Ink, which is a stylus for the Meta Quest. That‚Äôs definitely beyond the PC. So hopefully you get a sense of what we‚Äôll need to do more of in this space, but we know how to do it. I like this example a lot, the MX Ink stylus for Meta, because it‚Äôs beyond the PC but also helps us think about work beyond the office. Who‚Äôs going to use that stylus? It‚Äôs creative people, it‚Äôs doctors. It‚Äôs not your traditional office worker.

One thing that‚Äôs really difficult about going beyond the PC is that there are vastly more gatekeepers once you leave the realm of Mac and Windows. It‚Äôs Apple and Google in particular. There are things that they will simply not allow you to do with their devices. There‚Äôs software you can‚Äôt ship. There are drivers you can‚Äôt load. There are peripherals that won‚Äôt attach, all the way down the line. Has that been a bit of a wake-up call?

Well, it‚Äôs been an area where I‚Äôm actually very impressed. Logitech, I think, has the best set of partnerships in the industry, and it‚Äôs proud of it and it nurtures those partnerships. Whether it‚Äôs Microsoft, Alphabet, Meta, Apple, Zoom, we work closely with all of them, and we‚Äôre able to develop products with and for them, including Apple, which is fantastic but a little secretive at times, which is their right and they‚Äôre amazing.

We just came out with a Combo Touch for the new iPads, which is a beautiful product, and we work with Apple with Berlin walls around [those products]. So it‚Äôs kind of funny. My team in Taiwan who works on that, they were wearing T-shirts when I came that said, ‚ÄúMy work is so secretive, I don‚Äôt even know what I‚Äôm working on.‚Äù

[Laughs] That‚Äôs very good.

But that‚Äôs a really close collaboration with a fabulous company, Apple. MX Ink is an example of Meta. And obviously we‚Äôre very close in our video conferencing business and beyond to Microsoft, Google, and Zoom. It‚Äôs a unique set of partnerships. This company was born as an American and Swiss company. That neutrality of working with all these partners is where the Swissness comes to life best.

Let me ask you to compare more directly. A lot of times in the tech world when people complain about app store policies or restrictions on what the OS will let you do or the Apple tax, the immediate comparison is, ‚ÄúWell, Walmart controls what goes in its stores,‚Äù or, ‚ÄúTarget controls what goes in its stores.‚Äù You used to work on Head & Shoulders, and if you wanted the end cap at Walmart for Head & Shoulders, you had to pay them some extra money for additional marketing. The analogy is there. It comes up all the time.

You‚Äôre a very unique person to ask this question of, because I have always thought, well, Walmart has competition. If you‚Äôre not getting a favorable rate to put the shampoo in Walmart, you can go to Target or the grocery store or Walgreens or wherever else. The platforms do not have that in that way. Have you felt that yet in your seven months?

You‚Äôre right that they don‚Äôt in that way. If I use video conferencing as an example, there is competition. Microsoft is obviously very large, but there is Google and there is Zoom. We do work really well with all three of them and we value all three of them and we put significant resources against all three of them, and they do the same with us. It‚Äôs not like there‚Äôs only one. And that‚Äôs true when it comes to virtual reality as well as beyond the PC. It‚Äôs a real competitive advantage for Logitech to have this range of partnerships and not just be in bed with any one of them.

Are there things you‚Äôd like to build or ideas you‚Äôve heard that are being blocked by the various rules that the mobile platforms have in place?

No. Again, it‚Äôs been seven months so this may change, but from what I‚Äôve seen, we can talk about everything, including with the very big boys. I love that and I think that will lead to some really great innovation going forward.

But if you wanted to have the AI button on a keyboard connected to an iPad that brought up your overlay and Options Plus to create a prompt, Apple would simply not let you do that on iPadOS in the way that you can on Windows and macOS.

Yeah, and again, I‚Äôm not sure that‚Äôs something we would die on our sword for.

Makes sense. The other piece of the puzzle here is basically everybody at some point tells me that they won‚Äôt die on their sword to continue connecting to Apple, but it just seems very obvious to me that comparison to retail falls apart because there are so many more retailers.

Yeah, although Walmart, don‚Äôt underestimate the size of Walmart, certainly in the US.  

Fair enough. The other world Logitech lives in is the world of standards. There‚Äôs USB for however much you‚Äôre going to play in the smart home. There‚Äôs Matter. There‚Äôs Bluetooth. Every time we do an episode on standards, we discover it‚Äôs intensely political and almost not technical in a very specific way. Has that come up for you ‚Äî ‚ÄúBoy, we need to make sure that the next version of the USB standard can do all the things we want it to do‚Äù? Or are you saying, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to let the platforms figure that out‚Äù?

We‚Äôre really active in all of the industry forums and associations that talk about standards because it is really important for us, not just for the platforms. I would say the most important thing is that there is a standard because, when there isn‚Äôt, that just creates complexity and cost for everyone. We‚Äôre active and always trying to go for a standard.

I think we‚Äôll have to go to some new standards as well. One of the things I‚Äôm quite proud of at Logitech is that we carbon-label our products with a really solid methodology. It shows that your mouse is 1.5 in terms of emissions and your keyboard is 15 and your video conference, I don‚Äôt know by heart, but it‚Äôs a lot more. What would be super interesting is if we could get to an industry standard for carbon labeling so that consumers and corporate consumers can make a choice on a product that has lower emissions. That‚Äôs one of the things we‚Äôre trying to work with some industry associations and groups on. But in general, standardization is important for the industry, and we‚Äôll push that as hard as we can.

Did you open a door in some office at Logitech and find the people who have to work with the standards board and it‚Äôs just a group of sad lawyers?

They‚Äôre really exciting. They‚Äôre great.

I‚Äôm dying to know.

There‚Äôs not a lot of them. There‚Äôs like one, but they‚Äôre super active.

You‚Äôve talked about climate and sustainability several times now. Let‚Äôs talk about it in the context of AI. A bunch of the big companies, in particular companies investing in data centers and foundation models, they‚Äôre blowing their climate goals out of the water because they‚Äôre spending so much more in energy to power these AI systems. Those things are obviously in tension. You‚Äôre in on AI. You have Options Plus. You have the buttons on the mice. Then you‚Äôre also talking about being sustainable. How are you managing that tension?

Clearly we‚Äôre not building LLMs ourselves, so the impact of our stuff is very modest. It‚Äôs on the edge. In the context of our total footprint, we don‚Äôt expect that to have a significant impact. Our impact sits in materials and components, in PCBs and plastics, and it sits in the circularity, or the lack thereof. Because we sell stuff, hardware, and that‚Äôs a huge part of our footprint. 

So that is not where I‚Äôm concerned, but clearly, as an industry, we should be super concerned about the fact that pretty much every player has goals to be carbon neutral by 2040 or 2050, but right now the numbers are only going up and up and up. That is very concerning. We‚Äôre a relatively small player, but I hope we can be a pioneer and show the way on taking real climate action rather than just buying offsets.

Some of your goals are using more than 70 percent recycled plastic in manufacturing. Can you get to 100 percent? Is that feasible?

We should be able to get very close. The first priority for us on our glide path to a 50 percent emissions reduction by 2030 is to expand what we already know how to do. I‚Äôm really proud that Logitech is already at 75 percent of products using recycled plastic. That is huge. Unilever, Nestl√©, Procter & Gamble, they‚Äôre like 20 percent. This is huge on a large number of products every year. We also know what to do in terms of low-carbon aluminum, low-carbon some other things. We‚Äôve got to scale what we already know how to do, and I think we can get very close to 100 percent.

Then we have to use renewable energy wherever we can because that is a big part of our footprint. And then third and fourth, we have to innovate and we have to drive circularity. The last one is probably the hardest innovation to come. PCBs are a big focus for innovation. They‚Äôre a big part of our footprint as well, and they‚Äôre very carbon-intensive. We know what the four pillars are: We have to scale. We have to use renewable energy. We have to innovate, and we have to go for circularity. And then I think we have a fighting chance to actually be minus 50 percent and again grow the business because that‚Äôs the tricky thing here and that‚Äôs what Google and Microsoft are really struggling with right now.

Can you quickly define circularity?

The forever mouse, and the forever mouse could be the mouse that you keep and we just send you software updates, but it could also be the mouse that you turn in at Best Buy and we get it back or Best Buy takes it back and refurbs and resells it, which is another business model. We‚Äôre starting to do that but not yet at the scale that we need to.

Let‚Äôs end on the forever mouse because I‚Äôm fascinated by this concept: the idea that you would have a mouse and you‚Äôd buy it once and then you‚Äôd maybe pay some fees for software upgrades or you‚Äôd trade it in and get a newer one, and that would be a recurring revenue source for you. That all depends on a vision of what the mouse software should do besides just move the cursor around. But whenever we do episodes with anything to do with AI, our audience is like, ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt want this.‚Äù In a very direct way, sometimes they‚Äôre like, ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt want this and we especially don‚Äôt want it here.‚Äù

We might want it when we want it. I might want to use generative fill in Photoshop on my terms, but I don‚Äôt need it to follow me around the computer. And even if you‚Äôre saying the climate impact is minimal, I certainly don‚Äôt want to feel like there‚Äôs any climate impact of using my mouse and expanding the range of places where you might go ask OpenAI for inference. That‚Äôs one problem. The second problem is you‚Äôre still competing with OpenAI and Google and Apple to be the primary interface for their backend services, right? You‚Äôre not training your own model.

The question for me is really twofold. It‚Äôs one:  is there a vision beyond ‚Äúthe software will do more for you‚Äù than just drive your mouse around? And the second part is: even if it can do more, can you realistically compete against the giants that have every incentive to make sure that you never look anywhere else?

On the second piece, this company has been a human-technology interface for its entire existence. And while the mouse built this house and maybe there won‚Äôt be mice forever ‚Äî although I think there‚Äôll be mice for a long time to come ‚Äî we‚Äôve always been that human-technology interface. There were always people who said, ‚ÄúWell, Google and Microsoft won‚Äôt want you to be.‚Äù In fact, they often come to us and say, ‚ÄúWe want an interface.‚Äù So, that MX Ink, it‚Äôs not that we were pushing Meta really hard. It was Meta saying, ‚ÄúOh, we‚Äôd love for you to do something like this,‚Äù and us saying, ‚ÄúWell, we think we can.‚Äù

I think the big players will continue to want to work with players like us who have the luxury of focus. For us, a $40 million idea is 1 percent growth. Whereas, for Microsoft or Google, that‚Äôs nothing. That luxury of focus is important, and I think we‚Äôll continue to be a human-technology interface in that way. Should the mouse do more than just move the cursor? Absolutely. And it does that today, and I think similarly about being more productive with shortcuts to the large language models and all kinds of other things. The guy that I met at a barbecue over the weekend who has programmed 120 shortcuts on his mouse, that‚Äôs the kind of stuff that can extend human potential in ways that are healthier.

This idea ‚Äî that Logitech sits at a machine-human interface ‚Äî right now, it‚Äôs expressed in Options Plus. Your software that has AI in it is essentially prompt engineering, right? You‚Äôre guiding people through the process of making a prompt, which is, for better or worse, how we are all talking to AI right now.

Yeah, totally.

Is that it? Is that the vision? Is there a different vision? Is that just the stopping point right now?

No, I think we‚Äôre at the beginning of AI, and [with time], it will become multimodal and we won‚Äôt even need to build prompts because it will know what prompts we need. Things will evolve exactly how that will evolve. Who knows? But I think the human is going to be a limiting factor. Human hands, the human brain. I suspect we‚Äôll still need human-technology interfaces. They may not look exactly like what Logitech sells today, but I think the future for human-technology interfaces is really, really bright.

The danger there is that‚Äôs also what Apple and Microsoft and Google see. I talked to Sundar Pichai and Satya Nadella, and they happily tell me that AI is a platform shift. And what they mean is that it‚Äôs an interface shift, that we‚Äôre going to get the phone out of your hand or you‚Äôre going to deal with something else that is not Apple‚Äôs phone. That‚Äôs very much what they mean.

What they‚Äôre talking about is, ‚ÄúOkay, you‚Äôre going to talk to the computer. It‚Äôs going to do stuff for you.‚Äù Or, ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre going to issue a set of commands, and the computer will figure out how to do whatever task you want it to.‚Äù You can already see they‚Äôre getting there. You can see some of the demos of the concepts. Do you worry about that disintermediating Logitech?

Yeah, but again, there‚Äôs still going to be technology, whether that‚Äôs an AI button or something else. I think Logitech did a really fine job surviving the shift from PC to phone and still being a fabulous interface. I‚Äôm pretty sure that with the fabulous engineers and designers we have, we‚Äôll also be an interface to whatever‚Äôs next.

Well, that‚Äôs a great place to end it. Hanneke, tell the people what you think is next for Logitech. You‚Äôve been there for seven months. What‚Äôs the stuff you‚Äôre looking forward to now that you‚Äôve figured it out?

We‚Äôve got a great bunch of innovations coming up. I could tell you, but I‚Äôd have to kill you. [Laughs.] As we go toward the end of your holidays, I think we have a really bright fiscal year ahead, and then we‚Äôll continue to extend human potential in work and play.

I love it. Well, the mouse built this house. This is amazing. Thank you so much for joining Decoder.

Alright, it is so nice to see you, Nilay.

Decoder with Nilay Patel /

How do you like your survival games? A nice bit of wood chopping while the birds chirp? Gathering some mushrooms while you deflect a little goblin's swings? Stumbling parched through a desert as a bed of scorpions prick your ankles with deadly venom? Well, Enshrouded may provide some or none of these experiences, but what its latest update does is capture their spirit. You'll now be able to choose from several difficulty presets to dampen or spice up the game's challenge. Otherwise, there's new customisation options and some quality of life tweaks, too.

Across all of the game's modes (singleplayer, co-op, dedicated servers), there's now four standard settings: Default, Relaxed, Hard, and Survival. Default is recommended as a first-time gig for new players, Relaxed is for those seeking a chill base-building time, Hard increases the amount of enemies and makes them tougher, while Survival is "for those who seek some punishment with additional survival mechanics on top of more aggressive enemies". We're talking hunger and dropping your backpack on death - fun.

What's nice is that each of these modes can be tweaked for an added personal touch. Enemy damage, boss health, duration of buffs, and many other things can be toned up or down. The devs mention a "starvation mode", if you're feeling particularly masochistic.

Elsewhere, there's new improvements to blocking and parrying, as well as better transitions between weapon switches. Crafting menus also now have bigger preview images, and changes to their layout make them easier to navigate. Some points of interest have been reworked and new locations added to Blackmire and Kindlewastes, like temples, caves, and enemy camps.

In our Enshrouded review, Ollie thought it had the best building in the survival genre and reckoned it was well worth a play: "If you can get on with Enshrouded despite its early access quirks and underwhelming premise, you'll find a rock solid foundation for what I really believe could one day be one of the most popular and well-thought-of survival crafting games out there".

If you're keen (heh) to check out all the changes, you can peruse them over on Steam.

PlayStation has today unveiled a new DualSense controller, inspired by upcoming PS5 release Astro Bot.

The controller itself boasts all the features you would expect from a DualSense, such as adaptive triggers and haptic feedback. These will all come into play when Astro Bot releases later this year (although, with more textures to feel through the controller than with Astro's Playroom). So far, so normal.

Things get a little more exciting when you get to the cosmetic side of things, however. The upcoming controller has Astro's blue accents on the handles and buttons, some sci-fi style grooves and - the most eye-catching feature in every sense - Astro's "trademark playful pair of eyes" on the DualSense's touchpad.

"It is a true work of art, and we could not be happier with the end-result," Team Asobi studio head Nicolas Doucet said today. You can see a little teaser for the controller via the video below.

These Astro Bot controllers are limited edition. Pre-orders will begin at 10am in the UK on Friday, 9th August via direct.playstation.com, as well as select retailers. The controller will set you back ¬£69.99.

The controller itself will then launch on 6th September, to coincide with the PS5 release of Astro Bot.

As for Astro Bot, a couple of us have already been hands on with the upcoming PS5 exclusive, and come away impressed.

"It feels bold to say so early on, but if the demo's quality is representative of the full game, Astro Bot looks like a strong candidate for the top spot on my own game of the year list," Digital Foundry's John wrote after a little hands-on time with it last month.

item.title: New Bethesda Trademark Could Hint at Future Starfield DLC
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/new-bethesda-trademark-starfield

Bethesda has filed a new trademark that might hint at the existence of forthcoming Starfield DLC, or perhaps (although this is much more of a shot in the dark) a followup.

The trademark is for something called "Starborn", and its category is "recorded computer game software", which is essentially the generic category for games, DLC, and the like.

In case you haven't played Starfield (for which I really wouldn't blame you), the Starborn are a group of beings that appear a little ways into the game's main story. I don't want to spoil what they are or what they're about, but they're kind of a big deal in Starfield's universe.

Naturally, since this is just a trademark, there's no indication as to what "Starborn" could actually be, but it's most likely another expansion for the game, following on from the upcoming Shattered Space expansion, which is due to launch sometime this fall.

Since Shattered Space hasn't launched yet, it's likely going to be a while until we hear from whatever "Starborn" turns out to be, but count on it being the second major DLC for Starfield.

There is, of course, always the possibility that this could be a sequel to Starfield, but given how long the game took to make, as well as the fact that its first DLC hasn't yet been released, a second DLC pack is far more likely.

If you still haven't caught up with Starfield, it's Bethesda's latest open-world RPG along similar lines as games like Skyrim and Fallout (Bethesda's interpretation of the latter, that is).

The game revolves around a miner who inadvertently discovers an artifact that gives them a cosmic vision, leading them to an interstellar organization that aims to discover the truth behind said visions.

Originally announced in 2018, Starfield was originally set for release in 2022, but was delayed before finally seeing the light of day last year.

It was met with mostly positive reviews, although Bethesda itself responded to certain negative reviews on Steam in a way that did not exactly bespeak confidence in its game.

If you're interested, you can check out Starfield right now on PC and Xbox Series X|S.

Although we deem the Xbox Core Controller to be the best Xbox Series X controller overall, that doesn‚Äôt mean there aren‚Äôt other options available. In fact, depending on the types of games you play, you might prefer an alternative Xbox Series X controller - one you can customize, a budget-friendly option, or even something more suited to racing games.

TL;DR ‚Äì These are the Best Xbox Series X/S Controllers:

  • Xbox Core Controller - Best Overall
  • Turtle Beach Recon Wired Game Controller - Best Budget Option
  • PowerA Enhanced Wired Controller - Best Ultra Cheap Option
  • Xbox Elite Series 2 - Best High-End Option

  • PowerA MOGA XP5-X Plus - Best Game Pass Controller

Accessing all the buttons you need quickly is imperative during a competitive gameplay session. With so many third-party options on the table, you don‚Äôt just need to stick to the official Xbox controller that comes with your Xbox Series X. And the good news is, many of these work with a gaming PC or gaming phone.

Best Xbox Series X/S Controllers

1. Xbox Core Controller

Best Xbox Series X/S Controller

Xbox Core Controller

Enjoy the familiar Xbox layout on an ergonomic controller with remappable buttons, a tactile D-pad, and ample connectivity options.

  • See it on Amazon

Compatibility

Xbox, Windows, Android, iOS

Works well across many devices

When you purchase an Xbox Series X, it comes as standard with the Xbox Core Controller. There‚Äôs nothing particularly fancy about it, but when something works, and it works well, it can be hard to beat. The comfortable and familiar design compliments most types of games, and with a few upgrades here and there, you‚Äôll be able to enjoy enhanced grip, record gameplay, and remap the controller‚Äôs buttons with ease.

Using Xbox Wireless, the Xbox Core Controller connects seamlessly with your Xbox, but will also work with your PC and phone thanks to built-in Bluetooth support. The only real downside here is that the controller uses AA batteries, which feels a bit out of touch in this day and age. Still, there is the option to connect a USB-C to the controller, but that does mean you forego the controller‚Äôs wireless capabilities.

Still, if you can look past the minor flaws, the Xbox Core Controller is a solid option for your Xbox Series X|S, Xbox One, and other platforms. The textured grip is a real selling point, alongside the hybrid D-pad, custom button mapping, and dedicated (but slightly awkward) Share button.

Note that this is also our pick for the best PC controller to buy.

2. Turtle Beach Recon Wired Game Controller

Best Budget Xbox Series X/S Controller

Turtle Beach Recon Wired Game Controller

Packing loads of features, including two extra configurable back buttons and on controller audio customizations, this wired gamepad is an affordable standout.

  • See it on Best Buy

Compatibility

Xbox, Windows

Great access to voice and audio options

Loads of features at a not-so-premium price are on offer with the Turtle Beach Recon Wired Game Controller. For around $50, this gamepad features all the traditional buttons, triggers, and sticks of an Xbox controller, plus two extra back buttons that let you activate controls without taking your thumbs off the analog sticks. You can configure those two rear buttons to do whatever you please, including tuning thumbstick sensitivity for better accuracy.

The Turtle Beach Recon offers a well-constructed, comfortable-in-hand wired controller with ergonomic grips to ensure a firm hold even in the heat of battle. However, audio customizations make it a standout. When connecting your gaming headset to the controller, you can play around with various EQ settings, like SuperHuman Hearing, to pick up on audio cues you may otherwise miss. And simple on-control adjustments to the game/chat mix should make communication with your teammates a breeze.

3. PowerA Enhanced Wired Controller

Best Ultra Cheap Xbox Series X/S Controller

PowerA Enhanced Wired Controller

Grab this wired gamepad to save money while still getting all the inputs you need, plus vibration motors and two small buttons on its underside for shortcuts.

Compatibility

Xbox, Windows

If you‚Äôve constantly got buddies stopping by for quick games of Madden NFL 24, having a flight of controllers ready to play might be convenient. A super affordable option, like PowerA's Enhanced Wired Controller, is perfect to always keep on hand, ensuring no one misses out on playing. Coming in under $40, it‚Äôs cheap but still offers a sturdy build that can hold up against any action you throw at it.

With looks and a feel similar to the standard Series X option, PowerA‚Äôs gamepad is easy to get the hang of. Its button, trigger, and stick layout are almost identical, though it weighs less and is a solely wired option. There‚Äôs even a built-in share button and mic mute switch, while mappable back buttons are handy for quicker actions in-game. Overall, the face buttons are highly responsive, and as a whole, the controller offers great functionality. You‚Äôll love this affordable gamepad as a backup option or even your mainstay, so you can spend money on some of the best game deals instead.

4. Xbox Elite Series 2

Best High-End Xbox Series X/S Controller

Xbox Elite Series 2 Controller

Get ample customizability on this high-end controller with a swappable controls, tunable triggers, extra rear paddles, and fully remappable buttons.

  • See it on Newegg

Compatibility

Xbox, Windows, Android, iOS

Battery

Rechargeable (40 hours)

The Xbox Elite Series 2 is a premium controller for hardcore gamers willing to pay the high price for greatness. All the buttons can be completely re-mapped, while four extra rear paddles can change the function of the face buttons when held down or have their own actions within a game. The rear paddles, D-pad, and thumbsticks are even attached magnetically for easy swapping to get your best feel, and the Elite 2 is even more customizable thanks to Xbox Design Lab.

As a wireless option, the Xbox Elite Series 2 has a built-in rechargeable battery that lasts up to 40 hours on one charge. So you won‚Äôt be hunting down AA batteries like the Core Controller. And in addition to Xbox Wireless, there‚Äôs Bluetooth connectivity and a USB-C for a wired option, making it easy to use with your PC or gaming phone.

5. Turtle Beach Stealth Ultra

Best Tunable Xbox Series X/S Controller

Turtle Beach Stealth Ultra

A display for setting adjustments and notifications, alongside hall effect sticks, tactile switches, and extra mappable buttons, makes this controller a standout.

Compatibility

Xbox, Windows, Android

Battery

Rechargeable (30 hours)

The Turtle Beach Stealth Ultra is a pro-level controller ready to be tuned to your ideal settings. Its reliable microswitch face buttons are remappable, and the four extra buttons on the rear can be assigned actions. There are hall-effect, anti-drift thumbsticks that you can dial in the performance of and come with interchangeable thumbsticks, while trigger stops to adjust actuation distance are ideal for FPS. Most of these settings can be modified using the controller‚Äôs companion app, but you may opt to use the rather unique on-gamepad ‚ÄúConnected Command Display.‚Äù

This compact, full-color screen directly on the Stealth Ultra displays phone notifications and allows you to make on-the-fly setting adjustments like swapping between ten different profiles, remapping buttons, fine-tuning the vibration intensity, and modifying RGB lighting. Given this is a wireless controller, you may think that the screen will significantly drain the battery, but Turtle Beach claims the battery lasts up to 30 hours, depending on the mode. It even comes with a handy quick charging dock so you can get back to the action in no time.

6. Scuf Instinct Pro

Best Competitive Xbox Series X/S Controller

Scuf Instinct Pro

Scuf pushes the boundaries of its controller, offering an ergonomic design with four rear paddles, interchangeable thumbsticks, and instant triggers.

Compatibility

Xbox, Windows, Android, iOS

The best controller to give you a competitive edge is the Scuf Instinct Pro. It rocks a look similar to the Core controller but includes some extras like four easy-to-use, customizable paddles. A switch near the triggers makes them actuate like a mouse click for a faster response time, which is a boon in shooters. Four interchangeable thumbsticks also let you find the best feel when annihilating your opponents.

The overall design of the Scuf Instinct Pro is something to marvel at, starting with the lightweight, ergonomic build, so even the longest gaming sessions won‚Äôt leave you fatigued. The grips on the rear of the handles also keep your hands firmly in place. However, when using the controller wirelessly, you‚Äôll rely on those pesky AA batteries.

7. Thrustmaster Eswap X Pro

Best Customizable Xbox Series Controller

Thrustmaster Eswap X Pro

Tinker around with different thumbstick and D-pad configurations thanks to its swappable, removable parts.

Xbox, Windows

Not aesthetically pleasing

If you want to perform next-level customizations to your controller, the Thrustmaster Eswap X Pro has you covered. It‚Äôs a modular option with swappable, removable parts, making it easy to tinker around with different configurations as the thumbsticks and D-pad pop right out. Therefore, you can go for the standard Core Controller layout or opt for something similar to the DualSense controller.

Packed to the brim with controls, the Thrustmaster Eswap X Pro has solid, tactile face buttons, while shortcut buttons on the rear keep your thumbs on the thumbsticks. There are six additional ‚Äúsettings‚Äù buttons and two switches to lock triggers for quicker firing. Its bulkier design may also be more comfortable for some than a traditional Xbox controller.

8. Thrustmaster TMX Force Feedback

Best Xbox Series X/S Racing Wheel

Thrustmaster TMX Racing Wheel

An affordable force feedback wheel for Xbox with ample buttons on the wheel, a paddle shifter, a control pad, and a two-pedal set for your gas and brake.

Compatibility

Xbox, Windows

Without a doubt, racing games like Forza Horizon 5 are best played on a proper racing wheel setup. Thrustmaster‚Äôs TMX Force Feedback offers ruggedness, and the feel of its components will impress anyone hitting the virtual open road. There is an insane amount of realistic, responsive force feedback that‚Äôs fine-tuned with a belt-pulley system, while the wheel has a non-slip grip and 900¬∞ rotation for ultimate precision.

The TMX Force Feedback has only two pedals, so you'll be shifting gears with the attached metal paddle shifters, similar to a real high-performance car. The button layout and styling also match that of a race car rather than a standard Xbox controller, but you still have all the controls you need to get by in games. Your Xbox should even automatically recognize the wheel, and it works seamlessly with your PC too.

9. Thrustmaster T-Flight HOTAS One

Best Xbox Series X/S Flight Stick

Thrustmaster T-Flight HOTAS One

Take it to the skies with an easy-to-use throttle and joystick featuring 14 buttons and switches along with five axes of control.

  • See it on Best Buy

Compatibility

Xbox, Windows

Are you ready to take it to the skies in Microsoft Flight Simulator? The best way to pilot your aircraft is with Thrustmaster‚Äôs T-Flight HOTAS One. This all-in-one flight stick is simple enough for rookie pilots to learn quickly, but seasoned veterans can still appreciate the realistic, ergonomic joystick and precise throttle to get up in the air.

The T-Flight HOTAS One offers a streamlined design with a sturdy base that connects the throttle and joystick, though you can separate them for your preferred setup. It‚Äôs easy to find the 14 different buttons and switches needed to perform actions in your game, while a share button captures views on your scenic flight. Five axes of control, a multidirectional hat switch, and a rapid-fire trigger further ensure you have the best flying experience possible.

See more of our picks of the best joysticks for additional options.

10. Honeycomb Aeronautical Alpha Flight Controls XPC

Best Flight Sim Controller

Honeycomb Aeronautical Alpha Flight Controls XPC

For a realistic and immersive flying experience, grab this yoke with a 180-degree rotation, 12-bit Hall Effect Sensors, and a durable build.

Compatibility

Xbox, Windows, Mac

For the most immersive experience in the virtual air, grab the Honeycomb Aeronautical Alpha Flight Controls XPC. This yoke totes the look and feel of one you‚Äôd typically see on an aircraft with a 180-degree rotation and 12-Bit Hall Effect Sensors for a smooth, realistic feel. A solid metal frame and shaft made of steel ensure this controller holds up, while a mounting system also lets you expand controls.

Speaking of controls, the Honeycomb Aeronautical Alpha Flight Controls XPC is packing tons for a more custom flight experience. On the handles are a variety of fully programmable buttons like an eight-way hat switch and two-way rockers switches for trim or aileron. Don‚Äôt worry the base also features buttons specifically for Xbox. Other features that mimic those of an actual airplane include a spring-loaded five-position ignition switch alongside a panel of master, alternator, avionics, and light switches.

11. PowerA MOGA XP5-X Plus

Best Xbox Game Pass Controller

PowerA MOGA XP5-X Plus

With a layout similar to an Xbox gamepad, this phone controller has a rechargeable battery that doubles as a phone charger, an adjustable phone clip, and Bluetooth connectivity.

  • See it on Amazon

Compatibility

Android, iOS, PC

Wired connection only for PCs

Do you enjoy gaming on the go? Xbox Game Pass makes that much easier, offering tons of your favorite console titles on your gaming phone. So grabbing a phone controller like the PowerA MOGA XP5-X Plus makes it much easier to play them. This option has a layout similar to the Xbox Core controller, but it manages to take things to another level for a better mobile gaming experience.

The PowerA MOGA XP5-X Plus offers Bluetooth 4.2 LE or USB wired modes for a simple connection to your smartphone. There‚Äôs even a 3,000 mAh rechargeable battery on board, which doubles as a phone charger, so you won‚Äôt need to worry about your device running out of juice halfway through a session. And a phone clip rests snuggly on the chassis, letting you game from multiple viewing angles and reduce fatigue, as it's ergonomically balanced.

Where to Get the Best Xbox Controllers in the UK

PowerA Enhanced Wired Controller
